Award.AwardTitle: Understanding the Communicative and Social Processes of Engineering Ethics in Diverse Design Teams

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
Within engineering design teams, engineering educators are concerned not only with how individual students develop ethically, but also how ethical decision-making emerges during team interactions and becomes integrated in design solutions. These ethical decisions often do not present themselves as traditional dilemmas, but are issues that are confronted in the everyday process of design, and are influenced by the cultural and disciplinary backgrounds of the members and the ethical climates of the team and the organization. This project seeks to understand how everyday ethical decision-making is integrated in the processes and interactions of diverse engineering design team and their recognition of the long-term design consequences of the solutions they produce. This study combines social network analysis with structuration theory to examine the structure of project teams while also examining the institutional and contextual factors that contribute to team climate, and to the development of group norms that affect team interactions.

Intellectual Merit: This study builds on prior NSF funded work and a broad literature from engineering education and the social sciences to address the compelling issue of ethical awareness and ethical reasoning within diverse design teams. Design is a central function of engineering and ethics is often learned within undergraduate design courses where many ethical decisions are made through smaller more frequent design decisions and involve interactions with team members. This project examines how everyday ethical decision-making is integrated systematically in the design processes and interactions of diverse design teams. The well-qualified research team will guide the study with an ambitious yet realistic research strategies, clear goals and objectives, and strong, multi-disciplinary evaluation and dissemination plans. Broader Impacts: The findings of this research have potential impacts across engineering education, as well as society. Today's technology provides the engineering community with an enormous opportunity to positively impact society if applied appropriately. Today's global society adds complexity to the social and ethical issues that need to be addressed by designers and professionals as technology is applied to address needs. Better understanding the development of ethical reasoning within diverse design teams as they make design decisions can greatly enhance the way engineers and other technical professionals learn key attributes called for by ABET, the NAE's Engineer of 2020, and industry stakeholders. The findings of this study can be used to inform curriculum, assessment, and pedagogical strategies that enable educators to guide students' ethical development across engineering. The project also introduces cross-disciplinary research methods from communication into engineering education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Background/Context: Engineering design work involves complex social processes and ethical decision-making. These ethical decisions often do not present themselves as traditional dilemmas, but are issues that are present in the everyday process of design, and are influenced by different priorities and concerns throughout the design process, the cultural and disciplinary backgrounds of the members, and the ethical climates of the team and the organization.  To prepare engineers capable of grappling with these ethical complexities, engineering educators need a richer understanding of how students engage in ethical decision-making in everyday design contexts, as well the characteristics of the team and organizational structure and processes that contribute to the students’ ability to make ethical design decisions within their project teams.

Purpose: To address this need, the project had three main objectives: (1) to develop an understanding of how everyday ethical decision-making is integrated systematically in the processes and interactions of diverse design teams; (2) to identify characteristics of the team structure and interactions that facilitate ethical decision-making processes of the students as well as contribute to their ability to make ethical design decisions within their project teams, and (3) to understand how ethical decision-making and associated team structures and processes shift throughout the design process and over time.

Approach: This project utilized a mixed-method, longitudinal approach which included semi-structured interviews, observations, and Social Network Analysis (SNA) survey data to examine how everyday ethical decision-making is integrated into team processes and the phases of the design process over time. The SNA survey data assessed seven different relations (e.g., technical, ethical, friendship, and program knowledge) between team members at multiple points in the study. Data were collected from four classes (sections) of a service-learning design program over three semesters.  The program is multi-disciplinary and vertically-integrated.  The projects often span multiple semesters and/or years, and students can participate multiple semesters in the course. 

Results: The findings suggest that students struggled to identify or articulate ethical concerns in the contexts of their own design projects and did not perceive their team members as resources for ethical decision-making. However, despite students’ inability to identify ethics explicitly, most students’ descriptions revealed orientations toward design that were shaped by the human-centered design concepts taught in their service learning class and influenced their ethical decision-making in their design work. Human centered design concepts also served as a resource for developing a sense of team social responsibility for their design work. Students often linked ethical concerns to the users themselves, especially in cases in which they felt socially “close” to their users or they felt there was a greater potential impact on their users. Finally, students’ friendships with their classmates influenced their willingness to rely on their classmates as technical and ethical resources.

Conclusions: This project generated insight into the underlying social and communicative relations that impact ethical decision-making in undergraduate engineering design teams.  In addition, by examining how students negotiate ethical decision-making throughout the course of the design process, the findings provide contextualized engineering ethics examples that can aid engineering educators to better identify and direct students toward ethical concerns. Furthermore, this study illustrated how activities such as interactions with stakeholders, feedback from peers, professors, and users, and documentation of their design decisions facilitated students’ reflection on their ethical reasoning and appeared to play a role in orienting students toward more ethical considerations, greater ethical sensitivity, and a more fully developed sense of social responsibility to their team and their stakeholder.
